Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Learned the basics of linear algebra, but we skipped over almost all "applications" of it. Moreover, I don't know how much of what I learned will actually carry over to next semester.
Learned matrix manipulation and properties.
I learned how linear algebra works and how it can apply to real-world problems.
I learned most of the necessary concepts in linear algebra.
Variety of linear algebra topics and how to computate.
I learned the basic concepts of linear algebra and computations involving matrices.
I learned about linear algebra and its algebraic and geometric applications.

I didn't feel like I learned very much useful information through this class. Although it is titled linear algebra with applications, it was very light on the applications. We learned many algorithms and theorems of linear algebra, but I honestly still have no idea how to apply them to solving useful problems outside of the class.
Lectures were kind of hard to understand and follow. Practice exams were very easy compared to the actual exams which were a throw off.
Linear algebra.
I learned how to apply matrix operations, theorems about matrices, rules and how to use them.
I learned about solving matrices, eigenvalues/vectors, and basic linear algebra skills.

This class is absolutely terrible and is without a doubt the worst class offered by the Yale Math department every year.

It seems the most incapable PhD student is assigned this class, given that Gilbert Strang's MIT lectures are available online. You will inevitably rely solely on Strang's MIT OCW lectures and textbooks, given Liu's teaching.
Gained a solid understanding of basic concepts in linear algebra: positive definiteness, eigenvalues/vectors, systems of equations, etc.

I didn't know what to expect from this class after having taken ENAS 194 last semester.  It was more laid back than that class, but I still learned a great deal about linear algebra and problem solving in general.
I improved in my ability to teach myself mathematical concepts and understand a math textbook. I also learned the linear algebra concepts on a somewhat surface level.
I learned a lot about matrices!
I learned a lot about matrices.
linear algebra
It's linear algebra.
I got a good overview of linear algebra (non-proof based).
I learned the basics of Linear Algebra and how to solve problems.
I mostly learned about matrices.

I found this course to be helpful in understanding linear algebra. I however felt it was difficult to interpret or be in the right mindset in class since it was not clear what topic we were learning was under, just that we were learning it. The book also based ideas on a large amount of assumptions that it expected us to know.
I learned a lot about vectors, matrices, and dimensions. Definitely an important prerequisite for other topics that require it such as artificial intelligence.
I learned the basic math behind linear algebra, but the applications part was severely lacking.

The basics of Linear Algebra was taught in this course: Matrices, Gaussian Elimination, Vector Spaces, Orthogonality, Determinants, Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors, as well as Positive Definite Matrices. Applications of Linear Algebra were not touched on at all.
This course, true to its name, taught me numerous applications of the principles of linear algebra, with a little bit of theory here and there to back them up.
The textbook we used had errors in the answer key, and some vague/unclear language - past versions of this course used a different textbook which was apparently better.
Good basis for matrix manipulation/linear algebra. However, despite the name, had very few applications.

The content of this course was interesting, but the textbook was trash. It used the most convoluted ways of explaining concepts and asking questions. I didn't feel like the p-sets always helped me grasp the material better. The fact that the class was based on the textbook made everything worse. Next year, please pick a better textbook.
This course was super disorganized and I hardly got anything out of the lectures. Discussion section was basically the only way I learned necessary concepts.
I wasn't too keen on the book, as a lot of the material could have been more concisely worded. Other than that, the class is straightforward.

I think that the lectures weren't very engaging, even though they were well-organized. I also feel like the real-world applications to this were missing. But it was pretty much what I expected for a linear algebra class!
Weak lecturer, very difficult to follow. Rather unengaging.
The lecture was unengaging and I felt that simple topics were taught in a way that made them seem complicated.

I think the textbook of the course should be changed -- it has frequent typos and is organized very poorly. It does not explain the material very clearly and does not include examples that actually demonstrate how a certain topic or decomposition method can be applied to a problem. There are a lot more recent textbooks that are much better at explaining the course material and have clearly worked example problems in each chapter.

However, I thought lectures were pretty clear and better organized than the textbook, which helped.

The exams in the course are often too long (especially the midterm, though this was rectified slightly with the final). They also have a section of problems where students must "construct a matrix" that satisfies certain properties, and while these problems are reasonable in theory, they often require arbitrary guessing and lucky application of certain matrix principles. I think that these types of problems don't accurately reflect students' understanding of matrix properties because they require a lot of guessing and luck with finding the right principles to apply. In the future, if the instructor wishes to continue to put these types of problems on exams, he should also include practice "constructing matrix" problems on the problem sets to expose students earlier to this type of problem. I think these types of problems are particularly difficult on exams because students don't have any exposure or practice with this type of thinking, other than a handful of practice problems on the practice final. 

I also wish the course focused more on the application of matrices, as such is indicated in the course title. The class focused heavily on theory and didn't really focus on the application side, which was a little disappointing.
Uninteresting lectures that are not completely related to the homeworks/material. Exams that are unnecessarily computation-heavy with messy numbers and square roots.

This course was very poorly taught. Class consisted of the professor literally transcribing his notes to the board with no further explanation. I felt I learned most of the content from doing the homework and not from going to class. Tests were also unnecessarily hard. Overall, I did not enjoy this class.

The weakness of this class is that it doesn't provide outside context to show how and why the various matrix decompositions, theorems, concepts, etc. are useful. I learned how to decompose matrices, take determinants, find eigenvalues, etc, but not why I'd ever want to outside of the class.
I thought the class was great! The lectures were at times a little bland but Yuchen explained everything in the book perfectly and PSETs and tests were very fair.
The practice exams can be more reflective of the exams and more opportunities to understand the material.
Good material, too few tests.

This course was a good mix of theory and practice. It's an applications class, so that's mostly what we focused on, but we got a decent amount of theory as well. I think it could be improved if we got more of a sense of real-world applications to data etc., not just problem solving without a real-world context. I also think that it was difficult to prepare for the exams because the problems we were given were often very different from the problem sets and exams--they were fair and on topic, it was just hard to prepare for the types of questions we got. The exam practice questions were very simple and the problems on the tests complex, so even if you understood the material it was difficult to prepare for how to go about the problems.

Strengths: taught the basic linear algebra skills.
Weaknesses: Different parts emphasized by different professors - not uniform material. A clear textbook/outline would help a lot.

Strength: Doable p-sets, straightforward teaching style 
Weakness: really, really difficult final exam... among the hardest I have taken in my five semesters here.

Strengths: The class is taught directly from the textbook, so one can just rely on Gilbert Strang OCW. 

Weaknesses: The TA's can be quite good. Students were given insufficient time on the Midterm and no guidance was given on midterms nor finals.

My only critique of the course is that both exams were a little time constrained by the calculation sections, leaving less time to think about the matrix construction questions, which I believe are more interesting and also are more telling of a deep understanding of the material. 

Other than this, I thought the course was great-- in pace, content, everything.
This is one of the most poorly taught classes at Yale which is incrediby for par for the math department as a whole.
More conceptual questions (true/false, matrix construction) on the pset would have been helpful to prepare for the exam.

I thought the problem sets in this class were very helpful.  They covered a wide range of topics, didn't take too long to complete, and give me a sense that I really understood a lesson after completion.  On the other hand, I found the lectures to be sort of hard to follow at some points.  We would spend time talking about topics that didn't feel relevant to the lesson.

Super long psets and you will have to teach yourself. Professor Yuchen Liu gave terrible lectures that were ineffective in teaching any real material, but lectures were decently helpful for examples of concepts that the textbook doesn't touch on.

This course was unclear and poorly taught. The material itself was not very challenging, but I lacked an understanding of how various concepts related to each other and how to apply them to more than basic problems. I have very little understanding of why any of this material is important and what the real world applications are.
The course was not very clearly taught-- there was far too little time given on the midterm and I feel that some explanations weren't clear.
The course could have been taught better, with more emphasis on the applications.
There could be more applications.

This was the worst course I've taken at Yale. The professors lectures were unclear and gave no context. I took it over 225 because I thought it would be more straightforward but it felt like the professor designed tests to be intentionally tricky (used numbers that were hard to deal with and had problems that were not similar to the homework). take 225 instead

Gilbert Strang's textbook (the one used for this class) was terrible. It had so many typos, incorrect answers in the back of the book, and unexplained examples which was especially annoying in a class that emphasizes computation.

Yuchen (the professor) was very good. He gave the necessary examples in class, but unfortunately I didn't attend class enough to benefit from it. Overall, the class was very difficult (in my opinion), especially if you didn't have a good math background from high school. A lot of people in this class already took linear algebra which adds to the difficulty.

Pretty standard class taught pretty well. Professr Liu did a good job of summarizing and explaining each new concept.

I felt like there could've been more practice problems for the midterm and final, There was a pretty big jump in difficulty from practice to tests.

Linear algebra itself is pretty interesting, but this class was poorly taught. Lectures were extremely boring and not at all helpful for learning the material. You basically had to learn it all by yourself. In the future, this class definitely needs a better teacher. And there needs to be more time dedicated to understand the material, rather than just learning how to use equations.
Difficult test writing that focuses more on calculations than application.

The course could have had more regular assessments so that we weren't covering such large chunks of material at once. The book had mistakes. The final seemed more difficult than any other part of the class.
The class covers a lot of material, and it seems that semester to semester there is no consistency in course material taught.
I didn't really feel like I understood the context for what we were learning or how it could be applied, even though this was supposedly "Linear Algebra with Applications."

I found this course could be benefited by more structure and organization and more background on the material we learned in class and the topic it was under in Linear Algebra. I felt the concepts were relatively clear just not how they fit together.

The course covers a lot of material which is great. However, I believe that it would be better if we spend some time talking about the theory and the geometry so we better understand the computations that we carry out.

The strength was the TF and the weakness was the disorganization of the professor. He did not do a good job of explaining key concepts and jumps in logic he made. The exams were not well made. Making better tests and spending time answering questions and actually engaging with the class would be some ways to improve.

The course' textbook, Gilbert Strang's Linear Algebra and its Applications 4th Edition (2006), was a great resource to supplement (and some times substitute) the often confusing and hard to follow lectures. A second weakness of the course was the structure of the first midterm. The time allotted for the exam in relation to the difficulty and length of the exam's content led to the failure of many students to even finish the test. While I believe it was not the intention of Professor Liu to put his students in that position, I think the Math Department could have and should have offered him, a first-time professor, more support in teaching the course.

I know this is specific to the specific iteration of the course I took this past semester, but the discussion sections seemed to be this course's greatest strength. The graduate student TA, George Linderman, was wonderfully helpful and always explained concepts from class in much greater detail than Professor Liu. George's passion for the subject was plainly evident, and even a bit contagious; he really helped me enjoy the course.

As for weaknesses: the name of the course is "Linear Algebra with Applications," so one would expect that there would be more to the class than just the applications. That much was true. One would also expect that the theory behind those applications and algorithms would be emphasized so that students would understand the meaning behind the rote calculations instead of hastily mentioned and then never brought up again. That was not so. Coming away from the course, I remember all the kinds of decompositions and processes we learned, like Gram-Schmidt, normalization, QR decomposition, SVD, LDU decomposition, and so on, but it's much harder, if not impossible, for me to appreciate the value of those applications of linear algebra.

Furthermore, I fail to understand the reasoning behind Professor Liu's prohibition of calculators on exams. It's quite obvious that we're not being tested on our arithmetic skills, so what's the point in forcing us to do Gaussian elimination by hand every single time? If he suspected that we would use calculators to get the exact answers to every single question he asked, asking us to show our work in detail would have sufficed; no calculator I know of gives step-by-step solutions as opposed to just spitting out an answer.

No. Students were often left to learn concepts on their own because of how unclear class instruction was. Many students ended up resorting solely on the TF's section and on MIT lecture videos (made by the author of our textbook), as class time was useless.

I would recommend it to someone who is okay with teaching themselves. I felt like I had to teach myself from the textbook that didn't make sense before coming to class so that I would know what was going on. I would not recommend it to someone who is not naturally good with math.
Take this class if you have to. If not, it's really not worth the hassle. Lectures were not clear at all, and frankly Yuchen was not a great lecturer.

You may need this for some requirement, but it's not bad. The class is straightforward, and psets and exams are graded fairly. George as the TA is great! He and Professor Liu explain the concepts well.

This class is not "easy" like everyone said it would be, but definitely worth taking. Would recommend taking it with differential equations as well, as they are so related. Either way, the psets were challenging but very representative of what we were expected to know and the tests were tough but with the curve were fair. I liked Dr. Liu, and he was very supportive and patient in office hours. ALSO GO TO THE OPTIONAL SECTION. You learn the material so much better.
No. Too difficult to learn anything in lecture. Exams were SO difficult too.
Don't unless you have to take it.

Linear algebra is an important topic, so I would recommend this class for the content, but I would ask that the student shop the class for the professor and the textbook. If the textbook and professor are the same as this semester, I wouldn't necessarily recommend it to another student.

The quality of the course will vary with instructor. I would not take it with Yuchen. Lectures are dry, and exams are unnecessarily tedious with lots of computation and messy numbers and square roots. You're better off reading the textbook carefully then going to lecture.
Unless you need this for your major, I would not recommend this course at all if it's still taught by the same professor. Classes were not engaging and tests were unnecessarily difficult.
I would not recommend this course as it does nothing to contextualize the concepts you learn and they feel very meaningless in a vacuum.
Take it if you want an upper level math class. The material was actually really interesting but requires some work and engagement. Go to class its worth it!
Yes I enjoyed it.
If you need to know linear algebra but don't want proofs, take this course. Just make sure you work hard and get the concepts from the start.
I would recommend this course if necessary for your major - if not, take it credit/d.

I took this course from a social science background and thought it was not terribly difficult (probably somewhat easier than 120 for me), except for the final exam which was extremely challenging. It's a pretty straightforward math class-- we mostly learned the theory and not the applications.

Absolutely not.

Given that tuition for Yale was about $51,400 this year, this class works out to around $5,000. Since much of your learning will come from Strang's MIT OCW lectures and textbook which are: 

1. Free
2. Far superior to the teaching and guidance offered in this class

I really began to reconsider the value of tertiary education.
Definitely a good overview of basic concepts of linear algebra. You have to work quickly for the exams but the material is not too difficult.
I would recommend this class to someone who needs it to pursue higher learning in STEM.  I didn't necessarily enjoy it that much, but I can see how the skills will be necessary in future classes.
Not unless there is another professor teaching it.

I would not recommend this course. Although it is perhaps not as rigorous as MATH 225, I don't feel as if I've come away from the course with a very good understanding of the material. The class was poorly taught and unclear.
Only if it is required for the major.

I would not recommend. Take 225 instead. From what I've heard, the difficulty of this course can change a lot depending on the semester, but it is not worth the inconsistency. Take 225 - it is worth the tough psets.

If you're taking this class for personal knowledge as opposed to a requirement (which is what I did), I wouldn't recommend it. It's pretty hard, and a lot of people in the class took linear in high school which makes the curve unforgiving. Also, the average was always below 70 (failing) on all of the exams, so I feel that we had a harder class than is normally offered based off of others' experiences. Gilbert Strang's textbook was especially awful because the examples were unhelpful, the textbook was dense, and answers in the back were outright wrong which can be confusing/disheartening. 

Prof. Liu was a very good professor though, and coupled with Gilbert Strang's online lectures, you can learn a fair amount. Unfortunately, I learned this too late and assuredly didn't do very well in the course. If you have experience with math, you should be fine. Otherwise, be wary, attend lecture, and read the textbook before each lecture. I wasn't a fan of the course, and in retrospect would have avoided it.
If you have to, why not.

If you have to take linear algebra, you really don't have many options. I think this class probably would have been ok if it wasn't poorly taught. I had to spend a lot of time learning on my own for exams. Other than that, problem sets could be on the lengthy side, but they weren't that hard. Exams were fair, although a bit long. I'd recommend shopping around and seeing if you can find a good professor because it makes a big difference in linear algebra. If not, prepare yourself to watch a lot of MIT open courseware.
225 may bbe a better choice.
This class is a good way to get a basic foundation of LA without a lot of stress. I would recommend the course if you have a busy semester and its a prereq.
Not unless it is required. The PSETs are long and the teacher may or may not be good.

I might recommend Math 222 with Yuchen Liu to another student if you have to take linear algebra. Prof. Liu was a pretty decent lecturer-- he gave a ton of examples in class and was pretty clear when writing things on the board. But most of the material lacked context and we rarely got around to talking about the applications of linear algebra. And the homeworks (usually one pset per week, ~4-8 hours each) were difficult to complete without going to the TA's office hours.
If you want to learn learn about linear algebra and plan to take classes that apply it then it can be a good class.
Probably not with this professor, but if you have to take it for your major, then you can get through it with the help of the TF and using the book.

I would recommend this course to most students, but caution them that their enjoyment of the course and what they get out of MATH 222 depends heavily on the course instructor and their teaching style. However, any student willing to put in time by seeking resources outside of lecture is strongly advised to. The following resources helped: The course' textbook, Gilbert Strang's Linear Algebra and its Applications 4th Edition (2006), was a great resource to supplement (and often times substitute) the often confusing and hard to follow lectures. Gilbert Strang's MIT 18.06 Linear Algebra Lectures on MIT OpenCourseWare (on YouTube) can arguably replace most lectures altogether, however one shouldn't skip class because a course eval told you its possible.

I would recommend this course to a student pursuing a degree in computer science, perhaps, or possibly engineering, or some other discipline in which concepts from linear algebra arise, but I would certainly not recommend it to someone interested in any sort of a math major. Mathematics is about so much more than arithmetic, and that was, unfortunately, what too much of this course boiled down to.
